title: Day 1: Hello Universe
text:
hello universe, hello world :D


Creating Posts:

Navigate to “Data-As-Material-Class-Folder>posts” and create a new folder
lets name the folder “Day X”
Then proceed to “File>New File>Quarto Document”
Title and Author your document
Save the new document IN “DAY X” as index.qmd EACH TIME.

There can be only 1 index file in each folder!

title: Day 1: Hello Universe
section: My First Piece(s) of R Code
text:
My First Piece(s) of R Code

library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

library (ggformula)

Loading required package: scales

Attaching package: 'scales'

The following object is masked from 'package:purrr':

    discard

The following object is masked from 'package:readr':

    col_factor

Loading required package: ggridges

New to ggformula?  Try the tutorials: 
    learnr::run_tutorial("introduction", package = "ggformula")
    learnr::run_tutorial("refining", package = "ggformula")

library(babynames)


Lets look at every baby name from the US starting all the way from…


…..1880?!?!?

babynames

# A tibble: 1,924,665 × 5
    year sex   name          n   prop
   <dbl> <chr> <chr>     <int>  <dbl>
 1  1880 F     Mary       7065 0.0724
 2  1880 F     Anna       2604 0.0267
 3  1880 F     Emma       2003 0.0205
 4  1880 F     Elizabeth  1939 0.0199
 5  1880 F     Minnie     1746 0.0179
 6  1880 F     Margaret   1578 0.0162
 7  1880 F     Ida        1472 0.0151
 8  1880 F     Alice      1414 0.0145
 9  1880 F     Bertha     1320 0.0135
10  1880 F     Sarah      1288 0.0132
# ℹ 1,924,655 more rows




How many “Aditi”s have existed?

babynames %>% filter(name =="Aditi") %>% 
  gf_line(n~year)










What about “Adhithi”?

babynames %>% filter(name == "Adhithi") %>% 
  gf_line(n~year)










“Adithi”?

babynames %>% filter(name == "Adithi") %>% 
  gf_line(n~year)










or “Adhiti”?

babynames %>% filter(name == "Adhiti") %>% 
  gf_line(n~year)










In compiling them all into a single graph….

babynames %>% filter(name == "Aditi"|name == "Adhithi"|name == "Adithi"|name == "Adhiti") %>% 
  gf_line(n~year)










WOAHH!!


Although, my own name has some dissapointing results :(

babynames %>% filter(name == "Vasantha") %>% 
  gf_line(n~year)










My mother’s name seems to be faring better than mine, across the world..

babynames %>% filter(name == "Meena") %>% 
  gf_line(n~year)










As are her counterparts!!

babynames %>% filter(name == "Mina") %>% 
  gf_line(n~year)










And together…

babynames %>% filter(name == "Meena"|name == "Mina") %>% 
  gf_line(n~year)










:)

title: Day 2: Summarizing Data
text:
Installing packages makes them available to all documents created in the future. {syntax: install.packages(““)}
In each document however, one must call on the packages using {library()} to “activate” them.
Don’t forget to add { #| label: setup } in the first code chunk when calling the packages
Have only one quarto document open in one window, as R treats a session as a single data pool and can pull libraries across documents (which could complicate things later.

title: Day 3: Counts and Quantities
text:
Munging Data

Converting Qual Variables into Factors:

taxi_modifiedA <- taxi %>%
  dplyr::mutate(
    tip = as_factor(tip),
    local = as_factor(local),
    month = as_factor(month),
    dow = as_factor(dow),
    company = as_factor(company),
    hour = as_factor(hour)
    
  )
glimpse(taxi_modifiedA)

Ordered Factors - Levels and Labels

## Convert `dow`, `local`, and `month` into ordered factors
taxi_modifiedB <- taxi_modifiedA %>%
  mutate(
    dow = factor(dow,
      levels = c("Mon", "Tue", "Wed", "Thu", "Fri", "Sat", "Sun"),
      labels = c("Mon", "Tue", "Wed", "Thu", "Fri", "Sat", "Sun"),
      ordered = TRUE
    ),
    ##
    local = factor(local,
      levels = c("yes", "no"),
      labels = c("yes", "no"),
      ordered = TRUE
    ),
    ##
    month = factor(month,
      levels = c("Jan", "Feb", "Mar", "Apr"),
      labels = c("Jan", "Feb", "Mar", "Apr"),
      ordered = TRUE
    )
  )
taxi_modifiedB %>% glimpse()

title: Day 3: Counts and Quantities
section: Q1.A: Do more people tip than not?
text:
Q1.A: Do more people tip than not?

gf_bar(~tip, data = taxi_modifiedB) %>%
  gf_labs(title = "Plot 1: Counts of Tips")

title: Day 3: Counts and Quantities
section: Q2.A: Does the tip depend upon whether the trip is local or not?
text:
Q2.A: Does the tip depend upon whether the trip is local or not?

Notes:

color vs fill
where are the colours coming from
position: dodge vs stacked - DEFAULT IS STACKED



taxi_modifiedB %>%
  gf_bar(~local,
    color = ~tip,
    position = "dodge"
  ) %>%
  gf_labs(title = "Plot 2A.1: Dodged Bar Chart",
          subtitle = "Using Colour")









taxi_modifiedB %>%
  gf_bar(~local,
    fill = ~tip,
    position = "dodge"
  ) %>%
  gf_labs(title = "Plot 2A.2: Dodged Bar Chart",
          subtitle = "Using Fill")









taxi_modifiedB %>%
  gf_bar(~tip,
    fill = ~local,
    position = "dodge"
  ) %>%
  gf_labs(title = "Plot 2A.3: Dodged Bar Chart",
          subtitle = "Flipping 'local' and 'tip' variables:")









taxi_modifiedB %>%
  gf_bar(~local,
    fill = ~tip,
    position = "stack"
  ) %>%
  gf_labs(
    title = "Plot 2B.1: Stacked Bar Chart",
    subtitle = "Can we spot per group differences in proportions??"
  )









taxi_modifiedB %>%
  gf_bar(~tip,
    fill = ~local,
    position = "stack"
  ) %>%
  gf_labs(
    title = "Plot 2B.2: Stacked Bar Chart",
    subtitle = "Flipping 'local' and 'tip' variables:"
  )









taxi_modifiedB %>%
  gf_bar(~local,
    fill = ~tip,
    position = "fill"
  ) %>%
  gf_labs(
    title = "Plot 2C: Filled Bar Chart",
    subtitle = "Comparing using perecentages and ratios"
  )









Understandings from Graphs:

Plot 2B. 1: People tip more often than not, regardless of if the trip is local or not.
Plot 2B. 2: Majority of those who tip are going on trips that are not local. This may be true, but its not the whole truth.
BECAUSE PERCENTAGS MATTER - THE NUMBER OF TRIPS THAT ARE LOCAL AND NOT LOCAL ARE NOT THE SAME.
Plot 2C: Now we can say,

title: Day 3: Counts and Quantities
section: Q3: Do some cab companies get more tips than others?
text:
Q3: Do some cab companies get more tips than others?

taxi_modifiedB %>%
  gf_bar(~ company,
    fill = ~tip,
    position = "fill"
  ) %>%
  gf_labs(
    title = "Plot 3A: Filled Bar Chart",
    subtitle = "Comparing using perecentages and ratios by company"
  )









Re-Ordering the columns.

taxi_modifiedC <- taxi_modifiedB %>% 
  group_by(company) %>%
  summarise(tip_prop = prop(tip))%>% arrange(tip_prop)
taxi_modifiedC

taxi_modifiedC %>%

    fill = ~tip_prop,
    position = "fill"
  ) %>%
  gf_labs(
    title = "Plot 3A: Filled Bar Chart",
    subtitle = "Comparing using perecentages and ratios by company"
  )
